article.headline: The OECD warns a second virus wave is as likely as not â hereâs what that would do to the economic recovery
article.body: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development released its twice-a-year economic outlook on Wednesday, and unusually, presented two scenarios â one where the coronavirus continues to recede, and another where a second wave of rapid contagion erupts later in 2020. OECD Chief Economist Laurence Boone said both forecasts are equally probable. Both forecasts are sobering, but in the âsingle hit,â U.S. gross domestic product slides 7.3% in 2020 and grows 4.1% in 2021, and in the âdouble hit,â U.S. GDP slides 8.5% in 2020 and limps just 1.9% higher in 2021. The unemployment rate in the double-hit scenario shoots higher to 16.9% in the fourth quarter and falls to only 10% in the fourth quarter of 2021, whereas the jobless rate in the single hit slows to 10.4% this year and 8.2% in 2021. Testing, tracking, tracing and isolating may not be enough to prevent a second outbreak of the virus, Boone said, and sectors such as tourism, travel, entertainment, restaurants and accommodation wonât return to normal as long as no vaccine or treatment is widely available. âEven if growth does surge in some sectors, overall activity will remain muted for a while. Governments can provide the safety nets that allow people and firms to adjust, but cannot uphold private sector activity, employment and wages for a prolonged period,â he said, calling for more public investment in digital and green technologies.
